evolve::WorldObject

evolve::WorldObject Class Reference

#include <WorldObject.h>

Inheritance diagram for evolve::WorldObject:

List of all members.

Detailed Description

And object that glues together the physics of an object with it's geometry.

The link between ODE and OGRE. However, stepping the physical world should be done elsewhere. Be sure to call update()!

Hmm.. we may add some interface to this to determine the bounding box. Could use inheritance and override create(), but that may be to much of a pita.

Also, may want to add system member into this sooner rather than later. This would argue for an LSystemRemote class though...

Initialize a world object at 0,0,0 Does not actually create the object in the world.

Parameters:
name The name used to identify this object This is not the same as the name of the resource used to create thsi object Also, the scene node of this object will be named name + "Node". (unless this behavior is overidden)
root Ogre root object

Member Function Documentation

virtual bool evolve::WorldObject::create (  )  [inline, virtual]

This method is overriden by child objects to provide the ability for object to determine it's own geometry (vs.

by loading a resource, as below) e.g. SphereObject : public WorldObject would use this to make a sphere.

bool WorldObject::create ( const string &  resourceName,
double  posx = 0,
double  posy = 0,
double  posz = 0 
) [virtual]

Creates the geometry of the object from a given resource Returns false if this object should use a create(), and this does not apply.

Parameters:
resourceName The name of the resource. This is given in terms of Ogre resources (e.g. "ninja.mesh") This is not the same as the name of this object, which is maintained separately
posx The default x position of this object
posy Ibid.
posz Ibid.

Reimplemented in evolve::LSystemWorldObject, evolve::StaticSphereObject, and evolve::StaticWorldObject.

bool WorldObject::setPosition ( const vector< double > &  pos  )  [virtual]

Set the position of the object.

Use with care, as constantly resetting the position of the object may mess with the physics.

bool WorldObject::setLinearVelocity ( const vector< double > &  velocity  )  [virtual]

bool WorldObject::setMass ( double  mass  )  [virtual]

virtual bool evolve::WorldObject::addForce (  )  [inline, virtual]

saved for later.

physcis engine interface doesn't handle this yet.

bool WorldObject::update (  )  [virtual]

syncs the graphical object to any changes in the physical object.

(e.g., updates the position of the graphical object in response to any physics that occurred). call this OR grow every frame, but not both.

Reimplemented in evolve::LSystemWorldObject.

virtual bool evolve::WorldObject::grow (  )  [inline, virtual]

Allows us to extend update functionality, while still factoring out generic update code (or just ignore the generic behavior altogether) call this every frame.

Reimplemented in evolve::LSystemWorldObject.

WorldObject * WorldObject::breed ( WorldObject *  parent2,
unsigned int  swappiness 
) [virtual]

Creates a new object, with a system that is a cross between this one and the argument.

The object returned is always of the same type as the object whose method is called. Attempting to call a parents breed() method on a child object will fail!

Parameters:
parent2 the other object to use in the cross
swappiness how much swapping to do between this object and the argument. Not necessarily a direct probability. 0 means just return a copy of this object.
Returns:
the new object or NULL on failure (note, the cross of systems failing does not necessarily result in breed failure)

Reimplemented in evolve::LSystemWorldObject.

bool WorldObject::noPhysics (  )  [virtual]

Removes the object from the physical world but does not destroy any other state.

Useful for "storing" or "ghosting" them. calling create() after this call will add the physics state back in.

Reimplemented in evolve::LSystemWorldObject.

bool WorldObject::restartPhysics (  )  [virtual]

bool WorldObject::noGraphics (  )  [virtual]

Inverse of noPhyiscs.

Removes the graphical state from the world, but continues to track the physics. calling create() after this call will add the physics state back in.

bool WorldObject::restartGraphics (  )  [virtual]

SceneNode * WorldObject::getSceneNode (  )  [virtual]

Returns the sceneNode for this object.

Note that the name of this node will be this->name + "Node" (unless overidden by child types)

pos the position of the object.

bool WorldObject::setInterpreter ( Interpreter *  interpreter  )  [virtual]

Sets the interpreter for this object.

Obviously, for interpreted system objects only (objects linked to an interpreted system that grows over time)

bool WorldObject::setSystem ( System *  system  )  [virtual]

Sets the system for this object.

Obviously, for growth object only (objects linked to a system that grows over time)
